revision.text:
{{Infobox magazine | title = First American Art Magazine | logo = | logo_size = | image_file = [[File:Faam_cover_1_fall_2013.jpg|180px]] | image_size = | image_alt = First American Art Magazine cover | image_caption = ''First American Art Magazine'',
N° 1, Fall 2013 cover,
artwork by [[Nani Chacon]] | editor = [[America Meredith]] | editor_title = Publishing editor | previous_editor = | staff_writer = | photographer = | category = [[Art magazine]] | frequency = Quarterly | format = Print and digital | circulation = | publisher = | paid_circulation = | unpaid_circulation = | circulation_year = | total_circulation = | founder = | founded = 2013 | firstdate = | finaldate = | finalnumber = | company = | country = United States | based = [[Santa Fe, New Mexico]] | language = English, primarily | website = {{URL|firstamericanartmagazine.com}} | issn = 2333-5548 | oclc = 840802595 }} The '''''First American Art Magazine''''' is a quarterly [[art magazine]] covering contemporary, historical, and ancestral [[art of Indigenous peoples of the Americas]].{{cite news |last1=Dávila |first1=Ungelbah |title=Joining the collective conversation: Two new magazines for and about Native artists make their debut |url=http://www.santafenewmexican.com/magazines/joining-the-collective-conversation-two-new-magazines-for-and-about/article_c669654c-0214-11e3-9b0e-0019bb30f31a.html |accessdate=28 September 2014 |work=[[Santa Fe New Mexican]] |date=10 August 2013}}{{cite web|last1=Irwin|first1=Matthew|title=Native American Artists Take Control of Their Market|url=http://hyperallergic.com/144781/native-american-artists-take-control-of-their-market/|website=[[Hyperallergic]]|accessdate=19 February 2015}} ==Background== The magazine was established in April 2013 "to provide a common platform for Native and non-Native academics, art professionals, artists, collectors, and other interested readers to seriously investigate and celebrate Indigenous American art—from ancestral to 21st century artwork."{{cite web |title=First American art magazine launches, bringing a uniquely indigenous voice to indigenous arts |url=http://artdaily.com/news/62312/First-American-art-magazine-launches--bringing-a-uniquely-indigenous-voice-to-indigenous-arts#.VCh17Ut_4ro |website=ArtDaily |publisher=Jose Viarreal |accessdate=28 September 2014}} The publishing editor is [[America Meredith]] ([[Cherokee Nation]]);{{cite news |last1=Staff |title=CN citizen launches ‘First American Art Magazine’ |url=http://www.cherokeephoenix.org/contents/details/7303 |accessdate=28 September 2014 |work=[[Cherokee Phoenix]]|date=29 May 2013}} literary editor is Matthew Ryan Smith, PhD; publicity director is Barbara Harjo; and circulation manager is Melissa Dominguez.{{cite web|title=About Us|url=http://firstamericanartmagazine.com/about-us/|website=First American Art Magazine|accessdate=10 November 2015}} ==Content== The magazine includes profiles of living Native artists, features articles, and several departments: Recent Developments (news); an "Exploring Native Graphic Design" column; Seven Directions (a top seven list); Advice; Art + Literature; memorials; classified advertising; and reviews of art exhibits, art books, and video/films.{{cite news |title=First American Art Magazine Is Online! |url=http://www.turtletrack.org/Issues14/CO02_2014/CO_0214_FirstAmericanArt.htm |accessdate=28 September 2014 |work=Cantu Ota |volume=12 |issue=2|publisher=Paul C. Barry|date=February 2014}} ==Distribution== FAAM is distributed by [[Disticor Magazine Distribution Services]], as well as directly by the publisher and at Native American art fairs and conferences. ==Honors== ''[[Library Journal]]'' selected ''First American Art Magazine'' as one of its Best Magazines launched in 2013, and wrote that, "A notable strength of the publication is its emphasis on the work of contemporary artists."{{cite news |last1=Black |first1=Steve |title=Best Magazines 2013 |url=http://reviews.libraryjournal.com/2014/04/best-of/magazine-recovery-best-magazines-2013/ |accessdate=28 September 2014 |work=Library Journal}} ==See also== * [[American Indian studies]] * [[Roy Boney Jr.]] * [[Kelly Church]] * [[Teri Greeves]] * [[Suzan Shown Harjo]] * [[Thollem McDonas]] ==References== ==External links== * {{Official website|http://firstamericanartmagazine.com/}} * [http://www.powwows.com/2014/06/19/first-american-art-celebrates-indigenous-art-and-artists/ "FIRST AMERICAN ART Celebrates Indigenous Art and Artists"], by Dawn Karima, powwows.com * [http://indiancountrytodaymedianetwork.com/2015/07/01/bringing-fresh-art-and-native-history-people-america-merediths-first-american-art-160630 "Bringing Fresh Art and Native History to the People"], by Jason Asenap, ''[[Indian Country Today Media Network]]'' {{NDNart|state=expanded}} [[Category:American quarterly magazines]] [[Category:American arts magazines]] [[Category:Independent magazines]] [[Category:Indigenous art of the Americas]] [[Category:Magazines established in 2013]] [[Category:Media in Santa Fe, New Mexico]] [[Category:Native American magazines]] [[Category:Native American studies]] [[Category:Native Americans in Santa Fe, New Mexico]] [[Category:Magazines published in New Mexico]]

{{other uses}} {{redirect-distinguish|Doctor House|House doctor (disambiguation)}} {{Use mdy dates|date=August 2018}} {{Infobox character | color = #d6d6ff | series = [[House MD (TV series)|House]] | name = Gregory House, M.D. | nickname = House | image = [[File:HouseGregoryHouse.png|250px]] | gender = Male | occupation = Head of Diagnostic Medicine | first = "[[Pilot (House)|Pilot]]" (1.01) | last = "[[Everybody Dies (House)|Everybody Dies]]" (8.22) | family = [[List of House characters#John and Blythe House|John House]] (legal father, deceased)
[[List of House characters#John and Blythe House|Blythe House]] (mother) | significantother = [[Stacy Warner]] (ex-girlfriend)
[[Lisa Cuddy]] (ex-girlfriend)
[[Dominika Petrova]] (ex-wife) | portrayer = [[Hugh Laurie]] | creator = [[David Shore]] }} '''Gregory House''', [[Doctor of Medicine|M.D.]] (born 1959) is the [[title character]] of the American [[medical drama]] series ''[[House (TV series)|House]]''. Created by [[David Shore]] and portrayed by English actor [[Hugh Laurie]], he leads a team of diagnosticians as the Head of [[Medical diagnosis|Diagnostic Medicine]] at the fictional Princeton-Plainsboro Teaching Hospital in [[Princeton, New Jersey]].{{cite web|url=http://www.tioti.com/show/housemd |title=House, M.D. |publisher=Tioti.com |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071012015231/http://www.tioti.com/show/housemd |archivedate=October 12, 2007}} House's character has been described as a [[misanthropy|misanthrope]], [[Cynicism (contemporary)|cynic]], [[Narcissism|narcissist]], and [[wikt:curmudgeon|curmudgeon]], the last of which was named one of the top television words of 2005 in honor of the character.{{cite web|url=http://www.languagemonitor.com/tv/tv |title=‘Refugee’ Tops ‘Desperation’ and ‘Camp Cupcake’ as Top Television Buzzword of the 2005 |publisher=The Global Language Monitor |date=June 18, 2008 |accessdate=March 17, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130515104011/http://www.languagemonitor.com/tv/tv/ |archivedate=May 15, 2013 |df= }} House is the only character to appear in all 177 episodes and, except for [[James Wilson (House)|Wilson]]'s brief appearance, is the only regular character to appear in the season six premiere. In the series, the character's unorthodox diagnostic approaches, radical therapeutic motives, and stalwart rationality have resulted in much conflict between him and his colleagues.{{Cite news|last=Kristine|first=Diane|publication-date=April 23, 2007| title=Ending Season Three With a Bang? An Interview with House Writer Lawrence Kaplow|periodical=[[Blog Critics]]| url=http://blogcritics.org/ending-season-three-with-a-bang/| accessdate=February 20, 2016}} House is also often portrayed as lacking sympathy for his patients, a practice that allots him time to solve pathological enigmas. The character is partly inspired by [[Sherlock Holmes]].{{Cite news|last=O'Hare|first=Kate|publication-date=January 5, 2005| title=Builder keeps adding on to "House" for Fox| periodical=seattletimes| url=http://www.seattletimes.com/entertainment/builder-keeps-adding-on-to-house-for-fox/| accessdate=February 20, 2016}} A portion of the show's plot centers on House's habitual use of [[Hydrocodone/paracetamol|Vicodin]] to manage pain stemming from a leg [[Limb infarction|infarction]] involving his [[Quadriceps femoris muscle|quadriceps muscle]] some years earlier, an injury that forces him to walk with a cane. This dependency is also one of the many parallels to Holmes, who [[Sherlock_Holmes#Drug_use|was a habitual user]] of [[cocaine]].{{cite news|url=http://holmes.spontaneousderivation.com/2008/05/31/a-house-md-and-sherlock-holmes-special-predicting-house-season-five-based-on-the-sherlock-holmes-canon/ |title=A House, MD and Sherlock Holmes Special: Predicting House Season Five Based On the Sherlock Holmes Canon |first=Arachne |last=Jericho |date=May 31, 2008 |publisher=Holmesian Derivations, ''A 21st century look at Sherlock Holmes.'' |accessdate=September 27, 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080913205215/http://holmes.spontaneousderivation.com/2008/05/31/a-house-md-and-sherlock-holmes-special-predicting-house-season-five-based-on-the-sherlock-holmes-canon/ |archivedate=September 13, 2008 |deadurl=yes }} The character received generally positive reviews and was included in several best lists.{{cite news|author=Davies, Hugh|date=November 20, 2004|title=Dr. Laurie has viewers of US TV in stitches|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|page=N9}}{{cite news|author=Bianco, Robert|date=November 16, 2004| url = https://www.usatoday.com/life/television/reviews/2004-11-15-house_x.htm| title = There's a doctor worth watching in 'House'| work=USA Today| accessdate = December 30, 2006|page=D1}} [[Tom Shales]] of ''[[The Washington Post]]'' called House "the most electrifying character to hit television in years".{{cite news| author=Shales, Tom|date=November 16, 2004| title = 'House': Watching Is the Best Medicine| work = [[The Washington Post]]|url = https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/articles/A53025-2004Nov15.html| accessdate = December 30, 2006}} For his portrayal, Laurie won various awards, including two [[Golden Globe Award]]s for [[Golden Globe Award for Best Actor – Television Series Drama|Best Actor in a Television Series – Drama]], two [[Screen Actors Guild Award]]s for [[Screen Actors Guild Award for Outstanding Performance by a Male Actor in a Drama Series|Best Actor from Drama Series]], two [[Satellite Award]]s for [[Satellite Award for Best Actor – Television Series Drama|Best Actor in a Television Series – Drama]], two [[TCA Awards]] for [[TCA Award for Individual Achievement in Drama|Individual Achievement in Drama]], and a total of six [[Primetime Emmy Award]] nominations for [[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Lead Actor in a Drama Series|Outstanding Lead Actor in a Drama Series]]. ==Character history== Gregory House was born to [[List of House characters#John and Blythe House|John and Blythe House]] on June 11, 1959,''No Reason'', S02E24 - after being shot, House is hospitalized. His hospital bracelet displays DOB as 06/11/1959, which is Hugh Laurie's birthdate. or May 15, 1959.S07E22 a medicine bottle lists his DOB as 05/15/1959 House is a [[Military brat (U.S. subculture)|military brat]]; his father served as a [[United States Marine Corps|Marine Corps]] [[United States Marine Corps Aviation|aviator]] and transferred often to other bases during House's childhood.{{cite episode| title = Daddy's Boy| episodelink = Daddy's Boy (House episode)| series = House, M.D.|airdate = November 8, 2005| season = 2| number = 5}} House presumably picked up his affinity for languages during this period and shows a level of understanding of Chinese, Greek,S06E19, "The Choice", while interacting with a patient. Japanese, Portuguese, Spanish, and Yiddish.His knowledge of Mandarin is evidenced in "Risky Business", S08E04, in conversation with his patient. One place in which his father was stationed was Egypt, where House developed a fascination with [[archaeology]] and treasure-hunting, which led him to keep his treasure-hunting tools well into adulthood.{{cite episode| title = Clueless| episodelink = Clueless (House episode)| series = House, M.D.|airdate = March 28, 2006| season = 2| number = 15}} Another station was Japan, where a 14-year-old House discovered his vocation after a rock climbing incident with his friend. He witnessed the respect given to a [[Burakumin|''buraku'']] doctor who solved the case no other doctor could.{{cite episode| title = Son of Coma Guy| episodelink = Son of Coma Guy| series = House, M.D.|airdate = November 14, 2006| season = 3| number = 7}} He also spent some time in the Philippines, where he received dental surgery. House loves his mother but hates his father, who he claims has an "insane moral compass", and deliberately attempts to avoid both parents. At one point, House tells a story of his parents leaving him with his grandmother, whose punishments constituted [[Child abuse|abuse]]. However, he later confesses it was his father who abused him.{{cite episode| title = One Day, One Room| episodelink = One Day, One Room| series = House, M.D.|airdate = January 30, 2007| season = 3| number = 12}} Due to this abuse, House never believed John was his biological father; at the age of 12, he [[Abductive reasoning|inferred]] that a friend of the family with the same birthmark as himself was his real father.{{cite episode| title = Birthmarks| episodelink = Birthmarks (House) | series = [[House (TV series)|House, M.D.]]|airdate = October 14, 2008| season = 5| number = 4}} In the episode "Birthmarks", House discovers that John is not his biological father after ordering a [[DNA profiling|DNA test]]. After a second DNA test was performed in the episode "Love is Blind", House discovers that the man he assumed to be his biological father, Thomas Bell, was not either.{{cite episode| title = Love Is Blind| episodelink = Love Is Blind (House)| series = House, M.D.|airdate = March 19, 2012| season = 8| number = 14}} The identity of his real father remains unknown. [[File:JHU15.jpg|thumb|right|House studied both as an undergraduate earning a BSc in physics and a medical student at [[Johns Hopkins University]]]] House first attended [[Johns Hopkins University]] as an undergraduate. Before fully committing to medicine as his discipline, he considered getting a [[Ph.D.]] in physics, researching [[dark matter]]. He was accepted to the [[Johns Hopkins School of Medicine]] and excelled during his time there. He was a frontrunner for a prestigious and competitive internship at the [[Mayo Clinic]],{{cite episode| title = Distractions| episodelink = Distractions (House episode)| series = House, M.D.|airdate = February 14, 2006| season = 2| number = 12}} but another student, Philip Weber, caught him cheating, resulting in his expulsion from Johns Hopkins and rejection from the internship. While appealing his expulsion, he studied at the [[University of Michigan Medical School]] and worked at a bookstore, where he met his future employer and love interest [[Lisa Cuddy]],{{cite episode| title = Humpty Dumpty| episodelink = Humpty Dumpty (House episode)| series = House, M.D.|airdate = September 27, 2005| season = 2| number = 3}} with whom he shared a night where "he gave her everything she asked for"{{cite episode| title = Top Secret | episodelink = Top Secret (House episode)| series = House, M.D.| airdate = March 27, 2007| season = 3| number = 16}}; years later, Cuddy noted that by that time, House, although still a student, had already become "a legend" due to his diagnostic brilliance. After the appeal process, he was denied re-entry into Johns Hopkins. During a medical convention in [[New Orleans]], House first saw his eventual best friend [[James Wilson (House)|Dr. James Wilson]]. Wilson, who was going through his first divorce at the time, broke a mirror in frustration and started a bar fight after a man repeatedly played "[[Leave a Tender Moment Alone]]" on a jukebox. Out of sheer boredom with the convention and to "have somebody to drink with", House paid for the damage, bailed him out, and hired an attorney to clear Wilson's name (who failed to do so), starting their professional and personal relationship. House says multiple times during the series that he is a "[[Board certified|board-certified]] diagnostician with a double specialty in [[infectious disease]] and [[nephrology]]."{{cite episode| title = Occam's Razor| episodelink = Occam's Razor| series = House, M.D.|airdate = November 30, 2004| season = 1| number = 2}} Approximately ten years before the beginning of the series, House entered into a relationship with [[Stacy Warner]], a [[constitutional law]]yer, after she shot him during a "Lawyers vs. Doctors" [[paintball]] match. Five years later, during a game of golf, he suffered an [[infarction]] in his right leg which went misdiagnosed for three days due to doctors' concerns. House would eventually diagnose the infarction himself. An [[aneurysm]] in his thigh had clotted, leading to an infarction and causing his quadriceps muscle to become [[necrosis|necrotic]]. House had the dead muscle bypassed to restore circulation to the remainder of his leg, risking organ failure and cardiac arrest. He was unwilling to allow an amputation opting instead to endure excruciating post-operative pain to retain the use of his leg. However, after he was put into a chemically induced coma to sleep through the worst of the pain, Stacy, House's [[medical proxy]], and Cuddy, who was House's doctor at the time, acted against his wishes and authorized a safer surgical middle-ground procedure between amputation and a bypass by removing just the dead muscle. This resulted in the partial loss of use in his leg and left House with a lesser, but still serious, level of pain for the rest of his life. House could not forgive Stacy for making the decision after he obviously didn't want it, and this was the reason Stacy eventually left him.{{cite episode| title = Three Stories| episodelink = Three Stories (House episode)| series = House, M.D.|airdate = May 17, 2005| season = 1| number = 21}} House now suffers [[chronic pain]] in his thigh and uses a [[Assistive cane|cane]] to aid his walking, though he often wields the cane for protection, pushing aside privacy curtains, stopping elevator doors, or knocking on doors. He also frequently takes [[Vicodin]], a moderate to severe painkiller, to relieve his pain. House does briefly break his dependency with psychiatric help, after he suffers a [[psychotic break]]. When Stacy makes her first appearance in season 1, she is married to a high school guidance counselor named Mark Warner.{{cite episode| title = Honeymoon| episodelink = Honeymoon (House episode)| series = House, M.D.|airdate = May 24, 2005| season = 1| number = 22}} Although she and House have a brief, intimate encounter during the second season, House eventually tells Stacy to go back to her husband, devastating her. In the season two finale "[[No Reason (House)|No Reason]]" one of House's former patients shoots him twice. At the beginning of season three, House temporarily regains his ability to walk and run after receiving [[ketamine]] treatment for his gunshot injuries.{{cite episode| title = Meaning | episodelink = Meaning (House)| series = House, M.D.| airdate = September 5, 2006| season = 2| number = 1}} However, the chronic pain in his leg comes back and House, who seems [[Depression (mood)|depressed]] because of the returning pain, takes painkillers and uses his cane once again.{{cite episode| title = Informed Consent | episodelink = Informed Consent (House)| series = House, M.D.|airdate = September 19, 2006| season = 3| number = 3}} The other doctors speculate his cane and [[opiate]] re-usage are due to his psychological tendencies. On a routine clinic visit, a police detective, [[Michael Tritter]], is seen by House. Tritter observes House taking Vicodin for his pain and blames this for House's being rude and a bully. Tritter, believing doctors should be more responsible while practicing medicine, decides to take it upon himself to take legal action to free House of his addiction by launching an investigation into suspected drug abuse. The investigation slowly involves Cuddy, Wilson and House's diagnostics team, with Tritter using extreme measures to get information. House, being forcibly weaned off Vicodin to take a deal where he would keep his medical license, goes to extreme lengths to manage his pain by stealing Oxycodone from a cancer patient of Wilson's who had just died, giving Tritter what he needed to bring House to trial. At the pretrial hearing, the Judge decides House is not a danger to society and that his pain management for his leg is not as serious as Tritter made it seem. This conclusion is reached when Cuddy manufactures evidence and perjures herself to keep House out of jail. During season five, House once again regains his ability to walk without pain after taking [[methadone]] but soon stops after nearly killing a patient due to an uncharacteristic medical error. At the end of season five, House's use of Vicodin reaches a level in which House starts hallucinating about a former fellowship candidate who is also Wilson's dead girlfriend Amber Volakis and a relationship with Cuddy. When House comes to the conclusion Vicodin is making him hallucinate and taking over his life, he checks himself into Mayfield Psychiatric Hospital. At the start of season six, after spending time in Mayfield, House stops taking pain medications and with the help of Dr. Darryl Nolan, finds other ways to deal with his pain and other aspects of his life. During his stay it is revealed by Dr. Nolan that House suffers from [[clinical depression]], has antisocial tendencies, an inflated ego and severe trust issues. Dr. Nolan at one point even took House to a gathering in an effort to make House open up to people. To help manage his pain House finds a short-lived hobby in cooking. Thirteen (Remy Hadley), Cuddy, and Wilson discover House is very good at his new hobby, attributing this to House thinking of ingredients in terms of chemistry. House eventually finds the one thing that seems to help the pain go away: practicing medicine. After he diagnoses a patient online for his team (without their knowledge), and shows Dr. Nolan how this reduces his pain, Nolan suggests House resume his practice.[http://www.tv.com/house/epic-fail/episode/1296797/recap.html?tag=episode_recap;recap TV Guide House recaps] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091003020339/http://www.tv.com/house/epic-fail/episode/1296797/recap.html?tag=episode_recap%3Brecap |date=October 3, 2009 }} episode 5,15 In season seven, when Cuddy, who is House's girlfriend at this point, has a brush with death, House goes back on Vicodin in order to cope with the fear of losing her. Near the end of season seven, House finds out the experimental drug he had been using caused fatal cancerous tumors in all of the lab rats in the experiment. He gets a [[CT scan]] of his leg and finds three tumors close to the surface of the skin in his leg. He goes home, cleans his bathroom, and attempts to perform surgery on himself to extract the tumors in his bathtub.{{cite episode|title=After Hours| episodelink = After Hours (House)| series = House, M.D.|airdate = May 16, 2011| season = 7| number = 22}} In season eight, House finds himself in jail after running his car into Cuddy's house, which was shown in the ending of the season finale of season seven. There he finds his need for Vicodin is a weakness when an inmate makes House steal twenty pills of Vicodin or be killed. Throughout season eight, House's therapeutic use of Vicodin becomes more habitual, similar to his use before season five. The final season's opening episode partly explores what path an imprisoned House would take aside from practicing medicine, revealing [[physics]] as his other forte.{{cite episode| title = Twenty Vicodin| episodelink = Twenty Vicodin| series = House, M.D.|airdate = October 3, 2011| season = 8| number = 1}} The episode "Body & Soul" makes a nod to this with a reference to a [[particle physics]] text amongst his books, as mentioned by his then-wife [[Dominika Petrova]].{{cite episode| title = Body & Soul| episodelink =| series = House, M.D.|airdate = April 23, 2012| season = 8| number = 18}} House fakes his own death in the series finale, thus giving up his ability to practice medicine again, in order to spend time with Wilson, who has five months left to live. He does this in order to avoid being sent back to prison for destroying an [[Magnetic resonance imaging|MRI]] machine in a prank gone wrong. The series ends with House and Wilson riding off into the countryside on motorcycles, as [[Robert Chase|Dr. Robert Chase]] takes over House's department.{{cite episode| title = Everybody Dies| episodelink = Everybody Dies (House)| series = House, M.D.|airdate = May 21, 2012| season = 8| number = 22}} ==Personality== {|class="toccolours" style="float: right; margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 2em; font-size: 90%; background:#c6dbf7; color:black; width:37em; max-width: 40%;" |style="text-align: left;"|"Dr. House is a fascinating and daringly cantankerous enigma, the proverbial bitter pill who also happens to be a highly intuitive medical genius. He despises interacting with patients and prefers dealing with diseases – with medical mysteries that leave other doctors scratching their heads in befuddlement." |- |style="text-align: left;"| — [[Tom Shales]] describing the character. |} House frequently shows off his cunning and biting wit, and enjoys picking people apart and mocking their weaknesses. House accurately deduces people's motives and histories from aspects of their personality, appearance, and behavior.{{cite web| last=Holland| first =Roger| title =House: Season Four Premiere| publisher = PopMatters| date =May 1, 2006| url =http://www.popmatters.com/pm/tv/reviews/48955/house/| accessdate =September 27, 2007}} His friend and colleague Wilson says that while some doctors have the "[[Messiah complex]]" (they need to "save the world"), House has the "[[Rubik's Cube|Rubik's complex]]" (he needs to "solve the puzzle").{{cite web|url=http://blogcritics.org/archives/2007/10/30/114407.php |title=Dr. Gregory House: Romantic Hero |accessdate=February 9, 2008 |author=Burnett, Barbara |date=October 30, 2007 |publisher=[[Blogcritics]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080213083700/http://blogcritics.org/archives/2007/10/30/114407.php |archivedate=February 13, 2008 |df= }} House typically waits as long as possible before meeting his patients. When he does, he shows an unorthodox [[Doctor-patient relationship|bedside manner]] and uses unconventional treatments.{{cite news|url=http://blogs.usatoday.com/betterlife/2008/09/find-better-bed.html |title=Find better bedside manner |work=USA Today |author=Kelley, Sue |date=September 18, 2008 |accessdate=April 4, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081022180543/http://blogs.usatoday.com/betterlife/2008/09/find-better-bed.html |archivedate=October 22, 2008 }} However, he impresses them with rapid and accurate diagnoses after seemingly not paying attention. This skill is demonstrated in a scene where House diagnoses an entire waiting room full of patients in little over one minute on his way out of the hospital clinic.{{cite episode| title = Sports Medicine| episodelink = Sports Medicine (House episode)| series = House, M.D.|airdate = February 22, 2005| season = 1| number = 12}} House, although rarely visiting his patients, demonstrates that he is more than capable of using practical medical skills. For example, occasionally taking part in operations and reacting quickly when a patient has a cardiac arrest in front of him. Critics have described the character as "moody", "bitter", "antagonistic",{{cite news|author=Goodman, Tim|date=November 15, 2004|url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article/article?f=/c/a/2004/11/15/DDGSL9QOII1.DTL|title=Network meddling by Fox execs starts the deathwatch for 'House'|work=[[San Francisco Chronicle]]|accessdate=October 24, 2008}} "[[misanthropy|misanthropic]]", "[[cynicism (contemporary)|cynical]]",{{cite news|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/news/story/13893076/dr_feelbad_hugh_laurie_became_the_dark_prince_of_prime_time_by_playing_the_best_vicodinaddicted_t/2|title=Dr. Feelbad|work=[[Rolling Stone (magazine)|Rolling Stone]]|author=Strauss, Neil|date=April 5, 2007|accessdate=April 4, 2009}} "[[wiktionary:grumpy|grumpy]]", "[[wiktionary:maverick|maverick]]",{{cite news|url=http://blogs.thestage.co.uk/tvtoday/2007/11/top-5-grumpy-tv-doctors/ |title=Top 5 Grumpy TV Doctors(amended) |work=[[The Stage]] |author=Wright, Mark |date=November 6, 2007 |accessdate=April 4, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080416022939/http://blogs.thestage.co.uk/tvtoday/2007/11/top-5-grumpy-tv-doctors/ |archivedate=April 16, 2008 |df= }} "anarchist", "sociopath", and a "[[wiktionary:curmudgeon|curmudgeon]]".{{cite news|url=http://www.salon.com/mwt/feature/2007/05/29/hugh_laurie/|title=Stalking Dr. House|work=[[Salon.com]]|author=Burana, Lily|date=May 27, 2007|accessdate=April 4, 2009}} The Global Language Monitor chose the word "curmudgeon" as the best way to describe the character. Laurie describes House as a character who refuses to "obey the usual pieties of modern life" and expects to find a rare diagnosis when he is treating his patient. Many aspects of his personality are the antithesis of what might be expected from a [[physician|doctor]].{{cite journal | last=Poniewozik| first=James| date= November 22, 2004| title=Scorn is the Best Medicine| magazine=Time|publisher=Time Inc.|url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,995688,00.html| issn=0040-781X| accessdate=September 28, 2007}} Executive producer [[Katie Jacobs]] views House as a static character who is accustomed to living in misery.{{Cite news|last=Kristine |first=Diane |publication-date=April 23, 2005 |title=Behind "Half-Wit" and Beyond: An Interview with House Executive Producer Katie Jacobs |periodical=Blog Critics |url=http://blogcritics.org/archives/2007/03/05/110433.php |accessdate=March 5, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070307120521/http://blogcritics.org/archives/2007/03/05/110433.php |archivedate=March 7, 2007 |df= }} Jacobs has said that Dr. Wilson, his only friend in the show, and House both avoid mature relationships, which brings the two closer together. Leonard has said that Dr. Wilson is one of the few who voluntarily maintains a relationship with House, because he is free to criticize him. Although House's crankiness is commonly misattributed to the chronic pain in his leg, both Stacy and Cuddy have said that he was the same before the infarction.{{cite episode| title = Need to Know| episodelink = Need to Know (House episode)| series = House, M.D.|airdate = February 7, 2005| season = 2| number = 11}} To handle the chronic pain in his leg, House takes Vicodin every day, and as a result has developed an addiction to the drug.{{Cite news|last=Kristine |first=Diane |publication-date=October 24, 2005 |title=Constructing House: An Interview With House, M.D. Writer Lawrence Kaplow |periodical=Blog Critics |url=http://blogcritics.org/archives/2005/10/24/213107.php |accessdate=October 12, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071106012144/http://blogcritics.org/archives/2005/10/24/213107.php |archivedate=November 6, 2007 |df= }} He refuses to admit that he has an addiction ("I do not have a pain management problem, I have a pain problem"). However, after winning a bet from Cuddy by not taking the drug for a week, he concedes that he has an [[drug addiction|addiction]], but says that it is not a problem because it does not interfere with his work or life.{{cite episode| title = Detox| episodelink = Detox (House episode)| series = House, M.D.|airdate = February 15, 2005| season = 1| number = 11}} In the 2009 season House goes through detox and his addiction goes into remission, so to speak.{{cite episode|title=Words and Deeds|episodelink=Words and Deeds|series=House, M.D.|network=[[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]]|airdate=2007-01-01|season=3|number=10}} However, it does seem that House may have gotten over his addiction in the season 6 premiere.{{cite episode|title=Broken|episodelink=Broken (House)|series=House, M.D.|network=[[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]]|airdate=2009-09-21|season=6|number=01}} ''House'' creator [[David Shore]] told the ''[[Seattle Times]]'' in 2006 that Vicodin is "becoming less and less useful a tool for dealing with his pain, and it's something [the writers] are going to continue to deal with, continue to explore".{{cite news|title=Doctors find little humor in TV's handling of painkillers|url=http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/television/2002820070_tvdrugs22.html|author=Holston, Noel|publisher=''[[The Seattle Times]]''|accessdate=December 18, 2008 | date=February 22, 2006}} House openly talks about, and makes references to, pornography.{{cite episode| title = Babies & Bathwater| episodelink = Babies & Bathwater| series = House, M.D.|airdate = April 19, 2005| season = 1| number = 18}} In "[[Lines in the Sand (House)|Lines in the Sand]]", he returns the flirtations of an underage female who is a daughter of a clinic patient.{{cite episode| title = Lines in the Sand| episodelink = Lines in the Sand (House)| series = House, M.D.|airdate = September 26, 2006| season = 3| number = 4}} He regularly engages the services of prostitutes,{{cite news|title=Playboy Interview: Hugh Laurie|work=[[Playboy (magazine)|Playboy]]|pages=31–36 + 105|author=Hochman, David|date=February 2009}} of which his former female diagnostic team member Dr. [[Allison Cameron]] ([[Jennifer Morrison]]), who once had a crush on him, is aware.{{cite episode| title = Que Sera Sera| episodelink = Que Sera Sera (House)| series = House, M.D. |season=3 |episode=6}} He also likes to gamble, frequently making wagers. House speaks [[Multilingualism|multiple languages]], demonstrating fluency in English, Spanish, [[Russian language|Russian]],{{cite episode| title = Fall From Grace | episodelink = Fall from Grace (House)| series = House, M.D.|season = 7| number = 17}} [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]],{{cite episode| title = Fidelity| episodelink = Fidelity (House)| series = House, M.D.| season = 1| number = 7}} [[Standard Hindi|Hindi]], and [[Standard Mandarin|Mandarin]].{{cite episode| title = Sleeping Dogs Lie |episodelink = Sleeping Dogs Lie (House)|series = House, M.D.|season = 2|number = 18}} He listens to [[jazz]], plays the [[piano]] ([[Hugh Laurie#Music|as does Hugh Laurie]]) and has an interest in vintage [[electric guitar]]s. House has often credited guitarist/songwriter [[Eric Clapton]] and composer [[Giacomo Puccini]] as his biggest musical influences, drawing parallels to those of [[Hugh Laurie]]'s. He is an avid [[video game|gamer]] with a preference for [[handheld game console|handhelds]] (owning two Sony PSPs and three Nintendo handhelds, two Game Boys and a DS), is known to attend [[monster truck]] [[truck pulling|pulls]] with Wilson, and watch the soap operas ''[[General Hospital]]'' and the fictional ''Prescription Passion''. House is a fan of the [[Philadelphia Phillies]] and [[Philadelphia Flyers]]. He is also (as is Laurie) a motorcyclist, riding a [[Honda CBR1000RR]] Repsol Edition, license plate Y91, as seen in "Swan Song", "Help Me", "Deception" and "Post Mortem"; otherwise, he drives a [[Dodge Dynasty]] sedan. House is an [[atheist]]. He openly and relentlessly mocks colleagues and patients who express any belief in religion, deeming such beliefs as illogical. He does not believe in an afterlife because he finds it is better to believe life "isn't just a test". However, in the season four episode "[[97 Seconds]]", he expresses sufficient interest in the possibility of an afterlife to electrocute himself in an effort to find out; he is dissatisfied with the results and denounces the possibility of an afterlife.{{cite episode| title = 97 Seconds | episodelink = 97 Seconds (House)|series = House, M.D.|airdate = October 9, 2007| season = 4| number = 3}} This is also an example of House's tendency to self-experiment and submit to risky medical procedures in the name of truth. Over the course of the series, he disproves the effectiveness of a [[migraine]] cure by self-inducing a migraine and controlling the effects through drugs, undergoes a blood transfusion to assist with a diagnosis, and overdoses on [[physostigmine]] to improve his memory after sustaining head injuries, subsequently causing his heart to stop beating, then undergoes deep brain stimulation soon after.{{cite episode| title = You Don't Want To Know| episodelink = You Don't Want To Know (House episode)|credits=[[David Shore|Shore, David]]; Hass, Sara|series = House, M.D.|airdate = November 20, 2008| season = 4| number = 8|accessdate=November 1, 2008}}{{cite episode| title = House's Head| episodelink = House's Head|credits=[[David Shore|Shore, David]]; [[Peter Blake (writer)|Blake, Peter]]; [[Doris Egan|Egan, Doris]]; Friend, Russel; Lerner, Garett; [[David Foster (writer)|Foster, David]]|series = House, M.D.|airdate = May 12, 2008| season = 4| number = 15|accessdate=November 16, 2008}}{{cite episode| title = Wilson's Heart| episodelink = Wilson's Heart (House)|series = House, M.D.|airdate = May 19, 2008| season = 4| number = 16|accessdate=November 16, 2008}} In "[[The Fix (House)|The Fix]]", he steals experimental medicine only tested in rats to try and regrow his thigh muscle, eliminating his pain. In the following episode, "[[After Hours (House)|After Hours]]", he finds out that the medicine cause tumors, and operated on himself in his bathtub based on a CT scan. Ultimately he is unable to continue and eventually brought in Cuddy, who sends him to the hospital. {|class="toccolours" style="float: left; margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 2em; font-size: 90%; background:#c6dbf7; color:black; width:40em; max-width: 40%;" |style="text-align: left;"|"[House] enjoys pursuing the truth, and he knows we all see the world through our own lenses. He's constantly trying to strip himself of those biases, to get a clean, objective view of things." |- |style="text-align: left;"| — Shore to ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]''.{{cite news|url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117999278.html?categoryid=3530&cs=1|title=Fox's medical marvel stays on top|author=Werts, Diane|date=January 29, 2009|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|accessdate=April 5, 2009}} |} House frequently says, "Everybody lies", but jokingly remarked he was lying when he said it.{{cite news| last = Jensen| first = Jeff| date = April 6, 2007| title = Full 'House'|newspaper = [[Entertainment Weekly]]| pages=44–47| url =http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,20016394,00.html| accessdate = September 12, 2007}} House criticizes social etiquette for lack of rational purpose and usefulness. Dr. Cameron states in the first episode of the first season "House doesn't believe in pretense ... so he just says what he thinks".{{cite news|url=http://www.variety.com/review/VE1117925545.html?categoryid=32&cs=1&p=0|title=House Review|author=Lowry, Brian|date=November 15, 2004|publisher=''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]''|accessdate=December 23, 2008}} In the season three episode "Lines in the Sand", he explains how he envies an [[Autism|autistic]] patient because society allows the patient to forgo the niceties that he must suffer through. In the same episode, Dr. Wilson suggests House might have [[Asperger syndrome]], which is characterized by a number of traits found in House, such as difficulty accepting the purpose of social rules, lack of concern for his physical appearance, and resistance to change; though he later reveals to House that he does not truly believe this, and that claiming this was a part of a ploy to soften Cuddy's opinion of House. House is a strong nonconformist and has little regard for how others perceive him.{{Cite news| last=Winters| first=Rebecca| publication-date=September 4, 2005| title=Doctor Is in ... a Bad Mood| periodical=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]| url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,1101308,00.html| issn=0040-781X| accessdate=October 9, 2007}} Throughout the series, he displays [[Sardonicism|sardonic]] contempt for authority figures.{{cite episode| title = Control | episodelink = Control (House)|series = House, M.D.| airdate = March 15, 2005| season = 1| number = 14}} House shows an almost constant disregard for his own appearance, possessing a permanent stubble and dressing informally in worn jeans, wrinkled shirts over rumpled T-shirts, and sneakers. He avoids wearing the standard white lab coat to avoid patients recognizing him as a doctor, preferring a shabby blazer or, less frequently, a [[motorcycle jacket]].{{cite episode| title = Pilot| episodelink = Pilot (House)| series = House, M.D.|airdate = November 16, 2004| season = 1| number = 1}} ===Social behavior=== House does not have much of a social life, and his only real friend is Dr. James Wilson. Wilson knew House before the infarction and looked after him when House's relationship with Stacy ended. Dr. Wilson's moving into House's apartment after his failed marriage in "Sex Kills" symbolizes his taking emotional refuge in his friend.{{cite news| last =Ryan| first =Maureen| title ='House'-a-palooze, Part 3: Katie Jacobs|newspaper = [[Chicago Tribune]]| date =May 1, 2006| url =http://featuresblogs.chicagotribune.com/entertainment_tv/2006/05/houseapalooze_p.html| accessdate =October 12, 2007}} Although they frequently analyze and criticize each other's motives, Wilson has risked his career to protect House, including having his job terminated in the first season as an effort of Edward Vogler to dismiss House, and having his practice damaged by Detective Michael Tritter in an investigation of House's narcotics consumption."Whac-a-Mole". House, M.D.. November 21, 2006. No. 8, season 3. House has quietly admitted, at several instances, that he is grateful for Wilson's presence, including referring to Wilson as his best friend. When Wilson resigns and moves away from both New Jersey and House's friendship in the season 5 premiere, House is desperate to have his friend back, and hires a private investigator ([[Michael Weston]]) to spy on him.{{cite episode| title = Not Cancer| episodelink = Not Cancer| series = House, M.D.|airdate = September 23, 2008| season = 5| number = 2}} The two ultimately reconcile at House's father's funeral in a scene similar to their first meeting, only this time Wilson breaks a stained glass window with what appears to be a bottle of wine or alcohol in a moment of anger directed at House. In the series finale, House fakes his death both to get out of going to prison and to spend five remaining months with Wilson before he dies of cancer, after having spent the past third of the season helping him through difficult, risky and ultimately unsuccessful treatments and reckless "bucket list" wishes. Lisa Edelstein has said that despite his sardonic personality, House is a character who is reliant on people surrounding him. Edelstein says this characteristic is portrayed on several occasions in the third season, during which House's medical career is in jeopardy due to investigations by Det. [[Michael Tritter]] ([[David Morse (actor)|David Morse]]), who arrests him for possessing narcotics.{{cite episode|title=Fools for Love|episodelink=Fools for Love|series=House, M.D.|serieslink=House (TV series)|network=[[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]]|airdate=October 31, 2006|season=3|number=5}} House's legal trouble ends when Edelstein's character, Lisa Cuddy, commits [[perjury]] during his hearing. In Season 5, a relationship with Cuddy begins to blossom, as they are unable to deny feelings between each other.{{cite episode| title = Joy| episodelink = Joy (House)| series = House, M.D.|airdate = October 28, 2008| season = 5| number = 6}} They share a kiss in episode six "Joy" which sparked an ongoing romantic tension between them. When Cuddy's office is destroyed by a gunman and is being renovated, she moves into House's office in what Wilson believes to be an attempt to get closer to House. The two try to drive each other away, doing things to each other's office to make them worse, but in an uncharacteristically nice move, House has Cuddy's mother send her medical school desk for her new office as a surprise. Cuddy is touched by what he did, but is devastated when she spots him with a prostitute he hired, not knowing he had done so only to mess with Kutner and Taub. In the season finale "[[Both Sides Now (House)|Both Sides Now]]" it is confirmed that House wishes to pursue a romantic relationship with Cuddy. In this same episode he believes he has slept with Cuddy and informs Dr. James Wilson the following morning. This however is revealed to be a psychosis, which is a side effect of his Vicodin abuse. The House-Cuddy story culminates in the [[House (season 6)|season 6]] finale, "[[Help Me (House)|Help Me]]", when Cuddy cancels her engagement to [[Lucas Douglas|Lucas]] to face the inevitable realization of her loving House all along;{{cite episode|title=Help Me|episodelink=Help Me (House)|series=House, M.D.|credits=Yaitanes, Greg|network=[[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]]|airdate=2010-05-17|season=6|number=22}} they share a passionate kiss, thus hinting on mutual willingness to try to develop a real relationship.{{cite web|url=http://ausiellofiles.ew.com/2010/05/18/house-huddy-spoilers-season-finale/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100520165516/http://ausiellofiles.ew.com/2010/05/18/house-huddy-spoilers-season-finale/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=May 20, 2010 |title='House' exclusive: Huddy fans – your time has come! |author=Michael Ausiello |publisher=Entertainment Weekly |date=May 18, 2010 |accessdate=August 9, 2010 }} However, in season 7, this relationship is ended when House starts taking Vicodin again when he is faced with Cuddy possibly having a terminal illness. The season 6 finale “[[Help Me (House)|Help Me]]” shows that despite his personality, he cares a lot about his patients, especially those who he has formed an emotional bond. He cares to the point of relapsing his addiction to Vicodin. House has also been known to act as a mooch at times, frequently stealing food from Wilson. In "[[You Don't Want to Know]]", while House is searching for the cause of Thirteen's twitching, he claims to have stolen money from her wallet. In the same episode, Wilson later observes that House's blood type is AB, the universal recipient, reflecting his desire to take whatever he can. In another episode, he reveals to Wilson that he's been borrowing larger and larger sums of money from him without paying him back, just to see at what point Wilson would turn him down. ==Development== ===Conception=== {|class="toccolours" style="float: right; margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 2em; font-size: 90%; background:#c6dbf7; color:black; width:30em; max-width: 40%;" |style="text-align: left;"|"The title diagnostician of the show would be as smart a physician as [[Dr. Kildare]] and as sharp a sleuth as [[Gil Grissom]] of ''[[CSI: Crime Scene Investigation|CSI]]'', it was important to us that he be damaged, both emotionally and physically." |- |style="text-align: left;"| — Shore on House's creation. |} While the show was originally set to be a medical [[Procedural drama|procedural]], the idea changed when the writers started to explore the possibilities of a curmudgeonly title character. Shore traced the concept for the title character to his background as a patient at a teaching hospital.{{cite news|url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,1043940,00.html|title=Dr. Feelbad|newspaper=Entertainment Weekly|date=April 8, 2005|author=Jensen, Jeff|accessdate=December 7, 2008}} Shore recalled that "I knew, as soon as I left the room, they would be mocking me relentlessly [for my cluelessness...] and I thought that it would be interesting to see a character who actually did that before they left the room". Shore also based the character partly on himself: in a 2006 interview with ''[[Macleans]]'' he explained that he has a "cynical and cold attitude lurking within" him, and almost always agrees with House's point of view. A central part of the show's premise was that the main character would be disabled in some way. The initial idea was for House to use a wheelchair, inspired by the 1960s [[police drama]] ''[[Ironside (TV series)|Ironside]]'', but Fox turned down this interpretation (for which the crew was later grateful). The wheelchair became a scar on House's face, which later turned into a bad leg necessitating the use of a cane.{{cite web|author1=Shore, David |author2=Jacobs, Katie |year=2006|url=http://www.hulu.com/watch/21680/house-house---houses-disability#s-p2-st-i1|title=House's Disability|work=[[Hulu.com]]|publisher=[[The Paley Center for Media]]|accessdate=September 16, 2008}} House usually holds his cane on the same side as his injured leg; Shore explained: "Some people feel more comfortable with the cane in the dominant arm, and that is acceptable".{{cite book| last = Challen| first = Paul| title = The House that Hugh Laurie Built| publisher = [[ECW Press]]| date = October 2008| page = 106| isbn = 1-55022-803-X}} The cane tricks that are seen throughout the series are created by Laurie himself.{{cite news| last =Ryan| first =Maureen| title ='House'-a-palooza: On Omar Epps' Emmy bid, Wilson's messed-up life and stupid cane tricks|newspaper=Chicago Tribune| date =May 1, 2006|url =http://featuresblogs.chicagotribune.com/entertainment_tv/2006/05/house_isnt_wait.html| accessdate =October 12, 2007}} Cathy Crandall, costume designer for the show, created a look for the character that made it seem like he did not care about his clothing.{{cite news|author=Hochman, David|date=March 5, 2007|work=[[TV Guide]]|title=House Rules|pages=22–25}} She designed House with a wrinkled T-shirt, a blazer that is one size too short, faded and worn-in jeans and heather-gray rag socks. It was Laurie's idea to have the character wear sneakers, because he thought "a man with a cane needs functional shoes"; the Fox studios' wardrobe department kept thirty-seven pairs of [[Nike Shox]] on hand. House has worn T-shirts designed by famous designers such as [[Barking Irons]] and Lincoln Mayne, but also by less known designers such as Andrew Buckler{{cite news|title=Tee Time|work=[[TV Guide]]|date=March 22, 2006}} and Taavo.{{cite news|first=Michelle|last=Romero|date=May 13, 2008|url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,20199656,00.html|title='House': Head Case|newspaper=Entertainment Weekly|accessdate=October 17, 2008}} The shirts are usually kept tied in a ball overnight to get them to wrinkle. ===Casting=== When casting for the part started, Shore was afraid that in "the wrong hands", House would "just be hateful". The casting directors were looking for someone who could, as Shore described, "do these horrible things and be somehow likable without just, you know, petting a kitten". When Laurie was asked to audition for the role of House, he was filming ''[[Flight of the Phoenix (2004 film)|Flight of the Phoenix]]'' in [[Namibia]].{{cite video|people=[[Hugh Laurie|Laurie, Hugh]]|title=[[List of House episodes|House, Season 1]], Casting Session with Hugh Laurie|medium=DVD|publisher=Universal|date=2004|accessdate=December 14, 2008}} Laurie had no big expectations for the show, thinking that it would only "run for a few weeks".Challen, p. 38{{cite news|title=Man about the House |url=http://www.news.com.au/dailytelegraph/story/0,22049,22657520-5009160,00.html |author=Clune, Richard |publisher=''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' |date=October 28, 2007 |accessdate=December 19, 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090401170200/http://www.news.com.au/dailytelegraph/story/0%2C22049%2C22657520-5009160%2C00.html |archivedate=April 1, 2009 |df= }} He planned to audition for the roles of both James Wilson and Gregory House. However, when he read that Wilson was a character with a "handsome open face", he decided to audition solely for the role of House.{{Cite news|last=Byrne |first=Bridget |publication-date=November 23, 2004 |title=British actor set for U.S. fame with offbeat M.D. role |periodical=[[The Press-Enterprise (California)|The Press Enterprise]] |publication-place=[[Riverside, California]] |publisher=Press-Enterprise Company |url=http://www.pe.com/entertainment/stories/PE_Fea_Ent_housestar.a1444.html |accessdate=October 9, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090207000325/http://www.pe.com/entertainment/stories/PE_Fea_Ent_housestar.a1444.html |archivedate=February 7, 2009 }} Laurie chose not to change his clothing, but to remain in the costume he wore for the film; he also decided not to shave his beard. He put together an audition tape of his own in a Namibian hotel bathroom, the only place with enough light, while his ''Flight of the Phoenix'' co-stars [[Jacob Vargas]] and Scott Michael Campbell held the camera. He improvised by using an [[umbrella]] for a cane.{{cite news|url=http://www.buddytv.com/articles/house/how-hugh-laurie-got-into-house-20722.aspx|title=How Hugh Laurie Got into 'House'|publisher=[[BuddyTV]]|date=June 24, 2008|author=DeLeon, Kris|accessdate=December 11, 2008}} Laurie initially believed that James Wilson would be the protagonist of the show after reading the brief description of the character and did not find out that House was the main character until he read the full script of the pilot episode.{{cite episode|title=Hugh Laurie Interview|series=[[Inside the Actor's Studio]]|network=[[Bravo (US TV channel)|BRAVO Network]]|airdate=2006-07-31|season=12|number=189}}{{cite news|url=http://www.starmagazine.com/news/13242|title=House's Hugh Laurie Battling "Mild Depression"|newspaper=[[Us Weekly]]|date=October 30, 2007|author=Cina, Mark|accessdate=December 19, 2008 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080214103243/http://www.usmagazine.com/houses_hugh_laurie_battling_minor_depression |archivedate = February 14, 2008}} After he had watched casting tapes for the [[Pilot (House)|pilot episode]], [[Bryan Singer]] grew frustrated and refused to consider any more British actors because of their flawed American accents. Although Singer compared Laurie's audition tape to an "[[Osama Bin Laden|Osama bin Laden]] video",{{cite news|author=Brioux, Bill|date=November 14, 2004|title=Compelling 'House' Doctor|work=[[Toronto Sun]]|page=TV2}} he was impressed with Laurie's acting and, not knowing who he was, Singer was fooled by his American accent.{{cite news|author=Keveney, Bill|date=November 16, 2004|title=Hugh Laurie gets into 'House'|url=https://www.usatoday.com/life/television/news/2004-11-15-hugh-laurie_x.htm|work=USA Today|accessdate=October 26, 2008}} He commented on how well the "American actor" was able to grasp the character, not knowing about Laurie's British nationality. Although Laurie's appearance was very different from the way Shore pictured House, when he watched the audition tape, he was equally impressed as Singer.{{cite web|last=Frum |first=Linda |title=Q&A with 'House' creator David Shore |work=[[Macleans]] |publisher=Rogers Publishing |date=March 14, 2006 |url=http://www.macleans.ca/culture/entertainment/article.jsp?content=20060320_123370_123370 |accessdate=January 2, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071010052544/http://www.macleans.ca/culture/entertainment/article.jsp?content=20060320_123370_123370 |archivedate=October 10, 2007 |df= }} More famous (in the American market) actors such as [[Denis Leary]], [[Rob Morrow]] and [[Patrick Dempsey]] were also considered, but Singer, Shore, and executive producers [[Paul Attanasio]] and [[Katie Jacobs]] all thought Laurie was the best option and decided to cast him for the part.Challen, p. 39 Laurie was the final actor to join the cast of ''House''.{{cite news|date=June 12, 2006|author=Richmond, Ray|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|pages=S18–S24|title=Casting About}} After he was chosen for the part, Laurie, whose father [[Ran Laurie]] was a doctor himself, said he felt guilty for "being paid more to become a fake version of my own father". While Laurie has used an American accent before in the ''[[Stuart Little (film series)|Stuart Little]]'' films, he found it difficult to adopt for his role, saying that words such as "coronary artery" are particularly tricky to pronounce. ===Parallels to Sherlock Holmes=== [[File:Paget holmes.png|thumb|right|House and Wilson's relationship mirrors Holmes and Watson's (pictured) relationship.]] Similarities between House and the famous fictional detective [[Sherlock Holmes]] appear throughout the series;{{cite news|url=http://www.emmys.tv/events/2006/house-wrap.php |title=Hugh Laurie and Cast Make a House Call |last=Slate |first=Libby |work=[[Academy of Television Arts & Sciences]] |date=April 17, 2006 |accessdate=December 23, 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090209065302/http://www.emmys.tv/events/2006/house-wrap.php |archivedate=February 9, 2009 |df= }} Shore explained that he was always a Sherlock Holmes fan, and found the character's traits of indifference to his clients unique.{{cite web|author=Shore, David |year=2006 |url=http://www.hulu.com/watch/21606/house-house---developing-the-concept#s-p2-st-i1 |title=Developing The Concept |work=[[Hulu.com]] |publisher=[[The Paley Center for Media]] |accessdate=September 16, 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080913031621/http://www.hulu.com/watch/21606/house-house---developing-the-concept |archivedate=September 13, 2008 |df= }} The resemblance is evident in various elements of the series' plot, such as House's reliance on [[psychology]] to solve a case, his reluctance to accept cases he does not find interesting and House's home address, [[221B Baker Street]], which is the same as Holmes'."[[Remorse (House)|Remorse]]". [[House (TV series)|House, M.D]]. January 25, 2010. No. 12, season 6. Other similarities between the two characters are drug use (House battled a [[Vicodin]] addiction for years and Holmes was a recreational user of [[cocaine]]), successful detoxification (which proves to be only temporary in House's case), playing an instrument (Holmes plays the [[violin]] and House plays the guitar, piano, organ and [[harmonica]]) and a talent for accurately deducing people's motives and histories from aspects of their personality and appearance.{{cite web|url=http://www.tvsquad.com/2006/10/31/you-cant-have-house-without-a-holmes/|title=You can't have House without a Holmes|last=Ward | first=Julia|work=[[TV Squad]]|date=October 31, 2006|accessdate=April 5, 2009}} Shore has also explained that the name "House" is a play on the name "Holmes" via its phonetic similarity to the word "homes". The pun does not extend to the meaning of the names, as the [[Holmes (surname)|surname "Holmes"]] actually denotes that its initial bearers lived near or worked with holly or holm-oak trees, such that "Holl[e]y" or "Oak[e]s" would be a more literal equivalent.{{cite news|first= Wendell|last= Wittler|title= Living in a 'House' built for one|url= http://msnbc.msn.com/id/7518037|date=April 18, 2005|work=[[msnbc.com]]|accessdate=October 12, 2007}} Both Holmes and House each have one true friend, [[Doctor Watson|Dr. John Watson]] and Dr. James Wilson, respectively.{{cite news|title=House and Holmes parallels |date=January 2006 |work=[[Radio Times]] |publisher=[[BBC Magazines]] |page=57 |url=http://www.radiotimes.com/content/show-features/house/house-and-holmes-parallels/ |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5msfesWep?url=http://www.radiotimes.com/content/show-features/house/house-and-holmes-parallels/ |archivedate=January 18, 2010 }} Leonard has said that House and his character were originally intended to play the roles of Holmes and Watson in the series although he believes that House's team has assumed the Watson role.{{cite news| last =Ryan| first =Maureen| title ='House'-a-palooza, part 2: Robert Sean Leonard|work=[[Chicago Tribune]]| date =May 1, 2006| url =http://featuresblogs.chicagotribune.com/entertainment_tv/2006/05/houseapalooza_p.html| accessdate =October 12, 2007}} Shore has also said that Dr. House draws inspiration from Dr. Marc Chamberlain, a professor of neurology at the University of Washington, Seattle, and Dr. [[Joseph Bell]] (who was a teacher of Arthur Conan Doyle's and thus a chief source of inspiration for the creation of Holmes), who could "walk into a waiting room and diagnose people without speaking to them". In the season two finale "No Reason", House is shot by a man named Jack Moriarty, a name that coincides with Sherlock Holmes' adversary, [[Professor Moriarty|Professor James Moriarty]];{{cite web|last=Kristine |first=Diane |date=May 24, 2006 |title=TV Review: House Season Finale – "No Reason" |work=Blog Critics |url=http://blogcritics.org/archives/2006/05/24/011244.php |accessdate=October 9, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080911051928/http://blogcritics.org/archives/2006/05/24/011244.php |archivedate=September 11, 2008 |df= }} likewise, in the fifth season, Wilson uses [[Irene Adler]] as the name for an imaginary love interest of House,{{cite episode|title=Joy to the World|episodelink=Joy to the World (House)|series=House|network=[[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]]|airdate=2008-11-09|season=5|number=11}} the same name as the only female adversary Holmes ever encountered. ==Reception== Throughout the series' run, the character received positive reviews. [[Tom Shales]] of ''[[The Washington Post]]'' called House "the most electrifying character to hit television in years". House was featured on several best lists. In 2008, House was voted by [[BuddyTV]] second sexiest TV doctor ever, behind Dr. [[Doug Ross]] ([[George Clooney]]) from ''[[ER (TV series)|ER]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.buddytv.com/articles/house/move-over-clooney-house-is-her-21907.aspx|title=Move over Clooney, 'House' is Here|author=Diaz, Glen L.|work=[[BuddyTV]]|date=August 11, 2008|accessdate=October 4, 2008}} TV Overmind named House the best TV character of the last decade.{{cite news|author=TV Overmind |date=July 1, 2010 |title=The Top 10 TV Characters of the Decade |work=TV Overmind |url=http://www.tvovermind.com/tv-news/the-top-10-tv-characters-of-the-decade-16097/10 |accessdate=May 3, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140503194129/http://www.tvovermind.com/tv-news/the-top-10-tv-characters-of-the-decade-16097/10 |archivedate=May 3, 2014 |df= }} In June 2010, ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' also named him one of the 100 Greatest Characters of the Last 20 Years.{{cite web|title=The 100 Greatest Characters of the Last 20 Years: Here's our full list!|url=http://popwatch.ew.com/2010/06/01/100-greatest-characters-of-last-20-years-full-list/|work=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|publisher=[[Time Inc.]]|accessdate=July 7, 2012|author=Adam B. Vary|date=June 1, 2010}} He also appeared in ''Entertainment Weekly''{{'s}} "30 Great TV Doctors and Nurses".{{cite news|last=Wilkinson|first=Amy|title=House, Hugh Laurie {{!}} Paging Dr. Feelgood: 30 Great TV Doctors and Nurses – Photo 3 of 28|url=http://www.ew.com/ew/gallery/0,,20195774_20632270,00.html#20366174|work=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|publisher=[[Time Inc.|Time Inc]]|accessdate=January 24, 2013|date=June 15, 2009}} He was elected TV's Most Crushworthy Male Doctor over Doug Ross of ''ER'' in a poll held by ''[[Zap2it]]''.{{cite web|title=TV's Most Crushworthy Doctor (Male)|url=http://www.zap2it.com/news/pictures/zap-tv-most-crushworthy-awards-pics,0,2089692.photogallery?index=22|work=[[Zap2it]]|accessdate=June 9, 2012|author=Carina Adly MacKenzie}} [[Fox News]] placed the character among the Best TV Doctors For Surgeon General.{{cite news|title=The Best TV Doctors For Surgeon General|url=http://www.foxnews.com/photoessay/image/0107090958_M_docs_house_450-jpg|work=[[Fox News]]|accessdate=January 24, 2013|date=September 29, 2011}} For his portrayal, Hugh Laurie has won various awards, including two [[Golden Globe Award]]s for [[Golden Globe Award for Best Actor – Television Series Drama|Best Actor in a Television Series – Drama]], two [[Screen Actors Guild Award]]s for [[Screen Actors Guild Award for Outstanding Performance by a Male Actor in a Drama Series|Best Actor from Drama Series]], two [[Satellite Award]]s for [[Satellite Award for Best Actor – Television Series Drama|Best Actor in a Television Series – Drama]], and two [[TCA Awards]] for [[TCA Award for Individual Achievement in Drama|Individual Achievement in Drama]].{{cite news|url=http://abcnews.go.com/GMA/Entertainment/story?id=1512758|title=Loose Lips Backstage at Golden Globes|first=David|last=Blaustein|date=January 17, 2006|publisher=[[American Broadcasting Company|ABC News]]|accessdate=September 29, 2008}} Laurie has also earned a total of six [[Primetime Emmy Award]] nominations for [[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Lead Actor in a Drama Series|Outstanding Lead Actor in a Drama Series]] in 2005, 2007, 2008, 2009, 2010, and 2011.{{cite web|work=[[Academy of Television Arts & Sciences]] |date=July 17, 2008 |url=http://cdn.emmys.tv/awards/2008pte/60thpte_noms.php |title=60th Primetime Emmy Awards |accessdate=July 25, 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5msfotyxq?url=http://cdn.emmys.tv/awards/2008pte/60thpte_noms.php |archivedate=January 18, 2010 |df= }}{{cite web|url=http://www.emmys.org/awards/2007pt/59thnominations.php |title=59th Primetime Emmy Awards |accessdate=March 2, 2008 |work=[[Academy of Television Arts & Sciences]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080515194730/http://emmys.org/awards/2007pt/59thnominations.php |archivedate=May 15, 2008 |df= }}{{cite web|url=http://cdn.emmys.tv/awards/2009ptemmys/61stemmys_noms.php |title=61st Primetime Emmy Awards |accessdate=July 16, 2009 |date=July 16, 2009 |work=[[Academy of Television Arts & Sciences]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090718001718/http://cdn.emmys.tv/awards/2009ptemmys/61stemmys_noms.php |archivedate=July 18, 2009 }} ==Bibliography== * {{cite book|isbn=978-0-425-21230-1|title=The Medical Science of House, M.D.|author=Holtz, Andrew|publisher=[[Berkley Books]]|location=New York|year=2006}} * {{cite book|isbn=978-0-425-23893-6|title=House M.D. vs. Reality: Fact and Fiction in the Hit Television Series|author=Holtz, Andrew|publisher=[[Berkley Books]]|location=New York|year=2011}} * {{cite book|isbn=978-0-415-47913-4|title=House The {{Use South African English|date=November 2012}} {{Infobox company | name = Handspring Puppet Company | logo = | caption = | type = [[puppetry]] [[perform]]ance and [[scenic design]] | genre = | fate = | predecessor = | successor = | foundation = [[circa]] 1981 | founder = Adrian Kohler and Basil Jones<ref name= "bk"/> | defunct = | location_city = [[Cape Town]] | location_country = [[South Africa]] | location = Locations in [[South Africa]], [[England]], and the [[United States]] | locations = | area_served = | key_people = Thys Stander<ref name="ww"/> | industry = | products = | services = | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | aum = | assets = | equity = | owner = | num_employees = | parent = | divisions = | subsid = | traded_as = | homepage = {{URL|http://www.handspringpuppet.co.za/}} | footnotes = | intl = }} The '''Handspring Puppet Company''' is a [[puppetry]] performance and design company established in 1981 by Adrian Kohler and Basil Jones, situated in [[Cape Town]], [[South Africa]]. Thys Stander is the company's chief puppet maker.<ref name="ww"/>
==History== Jones and Kohler met at the [[Michaelis School of Fine Art]] in Cape Town.<ref>{{cite web|title=About the Company|url=http://www.handspringpuppet.co.za/|work=Handspring Puppet Company|accessdate=4 April 2011}}</ref> At first, they designed puppets for [[target audience|children-targeted]] productions, which Jones initially disliked. Kohler "introduced him [Jones] to the [[west Africa]]n tradition of puppetry for adults,"<ref>{{cite web|last=Costa|first=Maddy|title=The gay puppet stars of Or You Could Kiss Me|url=https://www.theguardian.com/stage/2010/oct/03/gay-puppets-war-horse|work=The Guardian|accessdate=4 April 2011|date=3 October 2010}}</ref> working with Malcolm Purkey and [[Barney Simon]], among others.<ref>{{cite book|last=Baraitser|first=Marion|title=Theatre of Animation: Contemporary Adult Puppet Plays in Context, Volume 10, Part 1|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bq6NCRi8P4UC&pg=PA86&dq=handspring+puppet+company&hl=en&ei=2QmaTbrHMqHE0QGcjujoCw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=book-preview-link&resnum=2&ved=0CDUQuwUwATgK#v=onepage&q=handspring%20puppet%20company&f=false|accessdate=4 April 2011|year=1999}}</ref>
== Productions and exhibitions == 1987 saw their exhibition of "Unmasking the Puppet" at [[UNISA]].<ref name= "bk">{{cite book|last=Rubin|first=Don|title=The World Encyclopedia of Contemporary Theatre: Africa|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=TIgS_Eij8SEC&pg=PA288&dq=handspring+puppet+company&hl=en&ei=CsWZTa_-Ku-K0QHdzIz5Cw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=book-preview-link&resnum=5&ved=0CEUQuwUwBA#v=onepage&q=handspring%20puppet%20company&f=false|publisher=Taylor & Francis|accessdate=4 April 2011|year=1997}}</ref> Prior to that, Esther van Ryswyk directed their puppets in a play called ''Episodes of an Easter Rising'' (1985), based on David Lyttons's radio special of the same name.<ref name= "bk"/> It premiered in [[Charleville-Mézières]], [[France]].<ref name="ww">[http://www.playbill.com/celebritybuzz/whoswho/biography/19727 "Handspring Puppet Company"], ''Who's Who'', Celebrity Buzz, accessed 3 April 2011</ref>
In 1997, they worked with [[William Kentridge]] on ''[[Ubu and the Truth Commission]]''.<ref>Kohler and Jones 2007, p. xvii.</ref> It premiered in [[Johannesburg]], [[South Africa]], on 26 May 1997.<ref>The world premiere of ''Ubu and the Truth Commission'' followed on 17 June 1997, at the Kunsfest in [[Weimar]].</ref> Kentridge had been working for some years with the Handspring Puppet Company in Johannesburg, most notably on ''Woyzeck on the Highveld'' in 1993 and ''Faustus in Africa'' in 1996. The latter, according to Kentridge, was "a huge undertaking",<ref>Kentridge 2007, p. ix.</ref> after which he and the company were on the look-out merely for something small to "do and survive".<ref name="Kentridge 2007, p. x">Kentridge 2007, p. x.</ref> Starting on 18 September 1998, ''Ubu and the Truth Commission'' played at the [[Kennedy Center]] in [[Washington, D.C.]], for four performances.<ref>{{cite web|last=McGrath|first=Sean|title=Footloose & Fugard to Highlight D.C.'s Kennedy Center 1998-99 Season|work=Playbill|accessdate=4 April 2011|date=27 August 1998}}</ref>
[[Yaya Coulibaly]]'s play ''Tall Horse'' (2006) toured [[Africa]] under the supervision and direction of the company.<ref>[http://www.handspringpuppet.co.za/html/frameind.html "Tall Horse"]. ''Handsrping Puppet Company''</ref> On 1 March 2011, Kohler and Jones demonstrated a [[hyena]] puppet used in ''Faustus in Africa'' (1995) at the [[TED (conference)|TED 2011]] event in [[Long Beach, California|Long Beach]], [[California]].<ref name="ted">{{cite web|last=TED Blog|title=The genius puppetry behind War Horse: Handspring Puppet Company|url=http://blog.ted.com/2011/03/30/the-genius-puppetry-behind-war-horse-handspring-puppet-company/|work=TED 2011|accessdate=4 April 2011|date=30 March 2011}}</ref>
The Handspring Puppet Company achieved critical acclaim when ''[[War Horse (play)|War Horse]]'' premiered in [[South Bank, London]], on 17 October 2007.<ref>[http://www.ltdb.co.uk/node/22446 "War Horse"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110724023504/http://www.ltdb.co.uk/node/22446 |date=24 July 2011 }} ltdb.co.uk, accessed 20 January 2010.</ref> For this show, Kohler and Jones worked with directors Marianne Elliott and Tom Morris and choreographer [[Toby Sedgwick]]<ref>{{cite web|last=Itzkoff|first=Dave|title=‘War Horse’ Corrals Its American Cast|url=http://artsbeat.blogs.nytimes.com/2010/12/20/war-horse-corrals-its-american-cast/?scp=3&sq=war%20horse&st=cse|work=The New York Times|accessdate=14 March 2011|date=20 December 2010}}</ref> to design and construct life-sized horse puppets, controlled by three actors – two to operate the legs and one to control the head and neck, with all three actors providing a variety of sound effects.<ref name="ted"/> The company won an [[Olivier Award]], [[Evening Standard Theatre Award]] and [[London Critics' Circle Theatre Award]].<ref>[http://www.playbill.com/news/article/115735-Hairspray-Wins-Four-2008-Laurence-Olivier-Awards-Including-Best-Musical "Hairspray Wins Four 2008 Laurence Olivier Awards Including Best Musical"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140324015047/http://www.playbill.com/news/article/115735-Hairspray-Wins-Four-2008-Laurence-Olivier-Awards-Including-Best-Musical |date=24 March 2014 }} playbill.com</ref><ref>[http://www.holidayextras.co.uk/news/theatre-breaks/evening-standard-nominations.html "Evening Standard nominations - 2007"] holidayextras.co.uk</ref><ref>[http://westend.broadwayworld.com/article/Critics_Circle_AwardWinners_include_Hairspray_Patrick_Stewart_20080129 ''Broadwayworld.com'']</ref> The show transferred to the [[West End theatre|West End]] on 28 March 2009,<ref>[http://westend.broadwayworld.com/article/WAR_HORSE_Opens_In_The_West_End_32809_20081218 "'War Horse' Opens In The West End 3/28/09"] broadwayworld.com, 8 December 2008</ref> and on 15 March 2011, the show premiered on [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] at the [[Vivian Beaumont Theater]].<ref> {{cite web |url = http://www.playbill.com/news/article/146000-Seth-Numrich-to-Lead-War-Horse-on-Broadway-35-Member-Cast-Announced |title = Seth Numrich to Lead 'War Horse' on Broadway; 35-Member Cast Announced |author = Hetrick, Adam |date = 20 December 2010 |work = |publisher = ''Playbill'' |accessdate = 27 February 2011 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110223210433/http://www.playbill.com/news/article/146000-Seth-Numrich-to-Lead-War-Horse-on-Broadway-35-Member-Cast-Announced |archivedate = 23 February 2011 |df = dmy-all }}</ref>
The company collaborated with [[Neil Bartlett (playwright)|Neil Bartlett]] on ''[[Or You Could Kiss Me]]'', which opened at the [[Royal National Theatre|National Theatre]] in London on 5 October 2010, following previews from 28 September. The show has been described as "an intimate history of two very private lives, lived in extraordinary times."<ref>{{cite web|last=Hetrick|first=Adam|title=Or You Could Kiss Me Opens at London's National Theatre Oct. 5|url=http://www.playbill.com/news/article/143608-Or-You-Could-Kiss-Me-Opens-at-Londons-National-Theatre-Oct-5|work=Playbill.com|accessdate=4 April 2011|date=5 October 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121020161735/http://www.playbill.com/news/article/143608-Or-You-Could-Kiss-Me-Opens-at-Londons-National-Theatre-Oct-5|archivedate=20 October 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref> It closed on 18 November 2010.<ref>{{cite web|title=Or You Could Kiss Me|url=http://www.nationaltheatre.org.uk/59865/productions/or-you-could-kiss-me.html|work=National Theatre|accessdate=4 April 2011}}</ref>
For the Broadway production of ''[[War Horse (play)|War Horse]]'', the company has received an [[Outer Critics Circle Award|Outer Critics Circle Special Achievement Award]] for "Puppet Design, Fabrication and Direction for ''War Horse''", and they are also a recipient of the 2011 [[Special Tony Award]].<ref name="ga">Gans, Andrew.[http://www.playbill.com/news/article/150211-Outer-Critics-Circle-Nominees-Include-Sister-Act-Anything-Goes-Book-of-Mormon "Outer Critics Circle Nominees Include 'Sister Act', 'Anything Goes', 'Book of Mormon' "] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110429190413/http://www.playbill.com/news/article/150211-Outer-Critics-Circle-Nominees-Include-Sister-Act-Anything-Goes-Book-of-Mormon |date=29 April 2011 }} playbill.com, 26 April 2011</ref><ref name="Tony">{{cite web| url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/lifestyle/style/tony-awards-2011-book-of-mormon-war-horse-take-top-honors-neil-patrick-harris-impresses-as-host/2011/06/13/AGEEXVTH_story.html |title=Tony Awards 2011: ‘Book of Mormon’, ‘War Horse’ take top honors; Neil Patrick Harris impresses as host |publisher=[[Washington Post]] |last=Marks |first=Peter |date=13 June 2011 |accessdate=4 September 2014}}</ref>
== Notes == {{reflist|2}}
== References == *Kentridge, William. "Director's Note". In ''Ubu and the Truth Commission'', by Jane Taylor, viii-xv. Cape Town: University of Cape Town Press, 2007. * Jones, Basil, and Adrian Kohler. "Puppeteers' Note". In ''Ubu and the Truth Commission'', by Jane Taylor, xvi-xvii. Cape Town: University of Cape Town Press, 2007.
